questions.text: What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mediastinum

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Common sites of extragonadal germ cell tumor –
  • ➤ Mediastinum (50-70%) Retroperitoneum (30-40%) Pineal gland (5%) Sacrococcygeal area (less than 5%)

  • ➤ Retroperitoneum (30-40%)

questions.text: Which of the following is the pattern of inheritance with the pedigree chart provided in the image? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial inheritance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by the transmission of a trait from an affected mother to all of her offspring, while affected males do not pass the trait to their children. This unique pattern is due to the inheritance of mitochondrial DNA, which is maternally inherited.
  • ➤ Example of Maternal/ mitochondrial inheritance diseases: Leber's Optic Neuropathy , MELAS Syndrome (Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like manifestation).
  • ➤ Leber's Optic Neuropathy

questions.text: Identify the Mallampati class of this patient? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Class II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mallampati classification is a useful tool for predicting the difficulty of intubation, with higher classes indicating more challenging airways. The image provided corresponds to Mallampati class II, where the soft palate and base of the uvula are visible.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a mass in the right kidney on a CECT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Renal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The case of an elderly man with a heterogeneous large renal mass in the CECT image suggests renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC often appears as a solid renal mass with areas of necrosis or hemorrhage that cause the heterogeneity in density seen on CT images. This type of cancer is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults and can present with various imaging appearances, but a large, irregular, and heterogeneous mass is highly suggestive.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Renal angiomyolipoma: Typically appears as a well-circumscribed mass with a significant fat component, which should show negative Hounsfield units (HU) on CT, which is not evident in the presented image.
  • • Option A. Renal angiomyolipoma:
  • • Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Generally presents as a well-circumscribed, homogenous mass with a central scar. It does not typically appear as heterogeneous as RCC.
  • • Option B. Renal oncocytoma:
  • • Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure with very well-defined borders and no solid components, which does not match the characteristics of the mass show
  • • Option D. Renal cyst:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient came with pain in the abdomen and on further imaging the following is obtained. What is the best management option for this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ureteroscopic removal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For symptomatic distal ureteric stones, ureteroscopic removal is typically the best management option due to its effectiveness and minimal invasiveness.

questions.text: All of the following can be used in first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP), except: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.correct_answer: D. Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate : This method is typically used for second-trimester abortions. It involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space to induce abortion. However, it is rarely used nowadays due to advancements in other safer and more effective methods. Medical methods of first-trimester abortion : Mifepristone + misoprostol : A combination of mifepristone (a progesterone receptor antagonist) and misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) is a common and effective method for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy. Surgical methods of first-trimester abortion : Manual vacuum aspiration : This is a safe and effective method for terminating a pregnancy in the first trimester. Dilatation and curettage : Another surgical method used to evacuate the contents of the uterus in the first trimester.
  • • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate : This method is typically used for second-trimester abortions. It involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space to induce abortion. However, it is rarely used nowadays due to advancements in other safer and more effective methods.
  • • Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate
  • • This method is typically used for second-trimester abortions. It involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space to induce abortion. However, it is rarely used nowadays due to advancements in other safer and more effective methods.
  • • This method is typically used for second-trimester abortions. It involves the instillation of ethacridine lactate into the extra-amniotic space to induce abortion. However, it is rarely used nowadays due to advancements in other safer and more effective methods.
  • • Medical methods of first-trimester abortion : Mifepristone + misoprostol : A combination of mifepristone (a progesterone receptor antagonist) and misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) is a common and effective method for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Medical methods of first-trimester abortion
  • • Mifepristone + misoprostol : A combination of mifepristone (a progesterone receptor antagonist) and misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) is a common and effective method for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Mifepristone + misoprostol : A combination of mifepristone (a progesterone receptor antagonist) and misoprostol (a prostaglandin analog) is a common and effective method for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy.
  • • Mifepristone + misoprostol
  • • Surgical methods of first-trimester abortion : Manual vacuum aspiration : This is a safe and effective method for terminating a pregnancy in the first trimester. Dilatation and curettage : Another surgical method used to evacuate the contents of the uterus in the first trimester.
  • • Surgical methods of first-trimester abortion
  • • Manual vacuum aspiration : This is a safe and effective method for terminating a pregnancy in the first trimester. Dilatation and curettage : Another surgical method used to evacuate the contents of the uterus in the first trimester.
  • • Manual vacuum aspiration : This is a safe and effective method for terminating a pregnancy in the first trimester.
  • • Manual vacuum aspiration
  • • Dilatation and curettage : Another surgical method used to evacuate the contents of the uterus in the first trimester.
  • • Dilatation and curettage
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Mifepristone + misoprostol : Mifepristone + misoprostol is a commonly used combination for medical termination in the first trimester.
  • • Option A. Mifepristone + misoprostol
  • • Option B. Manual vacuum aspiration : Manual vacuum aspiration is a standard procedure for first-trimester abortion.
  • • Option B. Manual vacuum aspiration
  • • Option C. Dilatation and curettage : Dilatation and curettage is another method used in the first trimester to terminate a pregnancy.
  • • Option C. Dilatation and curettage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Extra-amniotic instillation of ethacridine lactate is not used for first-trimester medical termination of pregnancy (MTP).
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg364,369, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg203
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 24 th edition pg364,369, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition pg203

questions.text: An intra-operative image of scrotal exploration is shown. Identify the pathology. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Testicular torsion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Testicular torsion presents as acute testicular pain and requires urgent surgical intervention. The characteristic appearance on exploration includes a discolored, possibly non-viable testis due to the loss of blood supply.

questions.text: A patient with nasal bleeding was found to have nasal polyps; histopathology post-excision is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rhinosporidiosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The histopathological image features large sporangia containing numerous spores, typical of Rhinosporidiosis.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Rhinoscleroma : Caused by Klebsiella, characterized by Mikulicz cells, not seen here.
  • • Option A. Rhinoscleroma
  • • Option C. Hemangioma : Vascular tumor that would show proliferating blood vessels.
  • • Option C. Hemangioma
  • • Option D. Coccidioidomycosis : Fungal infection, but its histology typically shows spherules, not sporangia with spores.
  • • Option D. Coccidioidomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis is characterized by its histopathology featuring large sporangia with spores, differentiating it from other nasal lesions such as Rhinoscleroma, Hemangioma, and Coccidioidomycosis.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a woman with atrophic vaginitis with complaints of itching? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Topical estrogen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Topical estrogen:
  • • Topical estrogen:
  • • Atrophic vaginitis, also known as vaginal atrophy, is a condition that commonly affects postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels. It leads to symptoms such as vaginal dryness, itching, and discomfort. Local estrogen preparations are preferred over systemic hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for the treatment of postmenopausal vaginal atrophy. This is because local treatments directly target the affected area and have fewer systemic side effects. The use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally, applied each day for 1 to 2 weeks, generally provides symptomatic relief for women experiencing atrophic vaginitis.
  • • Atrophic vaginitis, also known as vaginal atrophy, is a condition that commonly affects postmenopausal women due to decreased estrogen levels. It leads to symptoms such as vaginal dryness, itching, and discomfort.
  • • Local estrogen preparations are preferred over systemic hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for the treatment of postmenopausal vaginal atrophy. This is because local treatments directly target the affected area and have fewer systemic side effects.
  • • The use of 1 g of conjugated estrogen cream intravaginally, applied each day for 1 to 2 weeks, generally provides symptomatic relief for women experiencing atrophic vaginitis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Steroids: Steroids are not the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis. They do not address the underlying cause, which is the lack of estrogen.
  • • Option A. Steroids:
  • • Option C. Antihistamines only: Antihistamines may provide temporary relief from itching but do not treat the underlying cause of atrophic vaginitis, which is estrogen deficiency.
  • • Option C. Antihistamines only:
  • • Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as topical estrogen is the recommended treatment for atrophic vaginitis.
  • • Option D. None of the above:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis, particularly in postmenopausal women, is the application of topical estrogen to provide symptomatic relief and address the underlying estrogen deficiency.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1469, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecology
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1469, Speroff’s Clinical Gynecology

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient complains of a nodular lesion near the limbus as shown, with mild discomfort that resolves after treatment with the use of a topical drug. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Episcleritis presents as a mildly uncomfortable, nodular lesion near the limbus that responds to topical treatment, such as phenylephrine, and is often associated with autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs in leprosy treatment cause hyperpigmentation? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Clofazimine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Clofazimine is an antimicrobial agent used primarily in the treatment of leprosy. One of the notable side effects of clofazimine is skin pigmentation changes, which can manifest as hyperpigmentation. This occurs because clofazimine accumulates in the skin, leading to discoloration. The pigmentation typically appears as a reddish or brownish coloration and can be distressing for patients due to its noticeable cosmetic impact. The pigmentation is long-lasting and may take several months to years to fade after discontinuation of the drug.
  • • Clofazimine is an antimicrobial agent used primarily in the treatment of leprosy.
  • • One of the notable side effects of clofazimine is skin pigmentation changes, which can manifest as hyperpigmentation.
  • • This occurs because clofazimine accumulates in the skin, leading to discoloration.
  • • The pigmentation typically appears as a reddish or brownish coloration and can be distressing for patients due to its noticeable cosmetic impact.
  • • The pigmentation is long-lasting and may take several months to years to fade after discontinuation of the drug.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Dapsone: Dapsone is another drug used in the treatment of leprosy, but it does not cause hyperpigmentation. Its side effects include hemolysis and methemoglobinemia, especially in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • • Option A. Dapsone:
  • • Option B. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections, including leprosy, but it is not associated with hyperpigmentation. Its common side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances and tendonitis.
  • • Option B. Ofloxacin:
  • • Option C. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is an antibiotic used to treat several bacterial infections, including leprosy. It can cause reddish-orange discoloration of bodily fluids like urine, sweat, and tears but does not cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.
  • • Option C. Rifampicin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clofazimine is a drug used in leprosy treatment that can cause significant and long-lasting hyperpigmentation of the skin.

questions.text: Clonorchis sinensis is associated with which type of cancer? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cholangiocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Opisthorchis viverrini is the new name of Clonorchis sinensis. It is associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: Calculate the Downe score of a newborn who has cyanosis which improves on giving oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, air entry markedly decreased, RR 40 per minute? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Downe score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in newborns. A score of 6 in this case indicates moderate respiratory distress, characterized by cyanosis that improves with oxygen, mild to moderate retractions, grunting heard on naked ear, markedly decreased air entry, and a normal respiratory rate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a complaint of lower back pain. During the medical examination, it is discovered that the patient has prostate cancer. The medical team suspects that the cancer may have spread to the lumbar vertebrae. What is the likely route of spread for prostate cancer to the lumbar vertebrae? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Prostatic venous plexus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prostate cancer primarily spreads to the lumbar vertebrae through the prostatic venous plexus (Bateson plexus), which allows retrograde embolic spread to the spine.

questions.text: A young female presented with wheezing and shortness of breath with use of accessory muscles. She complains of similar episodes in the past in early mornings. Spirometry findings are as follows: FEV1/FVC ratio < 0.7 and FEV1 < 80% of the predicted value in a female patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Asthma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Asthma is characterized by episodes of wheezing, shortness of breath, and use of accessory muscles, which often worsen in the early mornings or at night. Spirometry findings typically show an obstructive pattern, with a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (< 0.7) and an FEV1 < 80% of the predicted value. This pattern is indicative of obstructive lung disease, which is consistent with asthma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) : ILD typically presents as a restrictive lung disease, not obstructive. It shows a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio and reduced lung volumes.
  • • Option B. Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD)
  • • Option C. Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) : IPF is a type of ILD and also presents with a restrictive pattern, not obstructive. It involves progressive fibrosis of the lung tissue.
  • • Option C. Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF)
  • • Option D. Silicosis : Silicosis is another form of restrictive lung disease caused by inhalation of silica dust, leading to fibrosis and restrictive spirometry patterns.
  • • Option D. Silicosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asthma is an obstructive lung disease characterized by episodes of wheezing and shortness of breath, especially in the early mornings, with spirometry showing a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio and FEV1.

questions.text: Folic acid deficiency in pregnancy may result in: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Folic acid deficiency during pregnancy is primarily associated with neural tube defects (NTDs). Ensuring adequate intake of folic acid, especially before and during early pregnancy, is crucial for preventing these serious congenital anomalies.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association related to HRT (Hormone replacement therapy) among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.correct_answer: A. Decreases risk of Colon cancer
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been associated with a decreased risk of colon cancer. Studies have shown that estrogen in HRT may have a protective effect against the development of colon cancer. This effect is believed to be related to estrogen’s impact on gastrointestinal mucosal growth and repair.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This option is incorrect. HRT, particularly with estrogen and progestin, is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Long-term use of combined HRT has been shown to elevate the risk of breast cancer in several studies.
  • • Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer:
  • • Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This option is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen (estrogen alone without progestin) increases the risk of endometrial cancer. To mitigate this risk, progestin is often added to HRT in women with an intact uterus.
  • • Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer:
  • • Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This option is incorrect. HRT is actually used prophylactically to reduce the risk of osteoporosis. Estrogen helps maintain bone density and prevent bone loss, which is beneficial in managing osteoporosis.
  • • Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Drug of choice to treat this condition is? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metronidazole

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient presents with foul-smelling vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of bacterial vaginosis (BV). In bacterial vaginosis, the correct treatment is Metronidazole .
  • • Metronidazole
  • • Bacterial vaginosis is often caused by an imbalance in the normal bacterial flora of the vagina, commonly involving Gardnerella vaginalis. The condition is diagnosed using Amsel's Criteria, which include: Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge : The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5 : This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test) : The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy : Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.
  • • Bacterial vaginosis is often caused by an imbalance in the normal bacterial flora of the vagina, commonly involving Gardnerella vaginalis. The condition is diagnosed using Amsel's Criteria, which include: Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge : The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5 : This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test) : The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy : Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.
  • • Bacterial vaginosis
  • • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge : The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor. pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5 : This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina. Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test) : The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide. Presence of Clue cells on microscopy : Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.
  • • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge : The discharge is typically thin and white, and may have a fishy odor.
  • • Thin, white homogenous vaginal discharge
  • • pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5 : This elevated pH level is higher than the normal acidic environment of the vagina.
  • • pH of Vaginal fluid > 4.5
  • • Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test) : The discharge develops a characteristic fishy odor when mixed with potassium hydroxide.
  • • Fishy odor of discharge on adding 10% KOH (Whiff test)
  • • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy : Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that have a stippled appearance due to adherence of bacteria.
  • • Presence of Clue cells on microscopy
  • • Metronidazole is the first-line treatment for bacterial vaginosis, and it is typically administered as oral tablets (500 mg twice daily for 7 days).
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Clindamycin : While Clindamycin can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis, it is generally not the first choice. Metronidazole is preferred due to its effectiveness and established use.
  • • Option A. Clindamycin
  • • Option C. Cotrimoxazole : This antibiotic is used for a variety of bacterial infections but is not effective for bacterial vaginosis.
  • • Option C. Cotrimoxazole
  • • Option D. Azithromycin : This is a macrolide antibiotic used primarily for sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia and is not used for bacterial vaginosis.
  • • Option D. Azithromycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis is Metronidazole.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6 th edition

Ans. B. Cellulose

  • ➤ Cellulose

  • ➤ Made up of β–Glucose residues

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior division of middle cerebral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior division of middle cerebral artery

questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the artery that passes in close proximity to this area is the middle meningeal artery.
  • • The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum. Once inside, it divides into anterior and posterior branches. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery ascends vertically to supply the dura and the calvaria. Importantly, this artery courses in close proximity to the pterion. A blow to the pterion can fracture the thin bone here and rupture this artery, leading to an epidural hematoma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • option A . Anterior division of middle cerebral artery : This artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes of the brain. After the middle cerebral artery (MCA) exits the lateral sulcus, it bifurcates into its anterior and posterior divisions. However, the MCA and its divisions run deep within the brain, within the depths of the lateral sulcus and over the insular cortex. While they are critical for brain function, they don't have a direct relationship to the pterion on the external surface of the skull.
  • • option A
  • • Anterior division of middle cerebral artery
  • • Option C . Posterior division of middle cerebral artery : Similar to the anterior division, the posterior division of the middle cerebral artery runs deep within the brain and does not have a direct relationship to the pterion.
  • • Option C
  • • Posterior division of middle cerebral artery
  • • Option D. Stem of middle meningeal artery: The stem of the middle meningeal artery is the segment between its origin (from the maxillary artery) and its bifurcation into anterior and posterior divisions. As it enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum, the stem is somewhat close to the pterion but it's the anterior division that actually courses near the pterion on the inner surface of the skull.
  • • Option D. Stem of middle meningeal artery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:
  • ➤ The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:
  • ➤ Frontal bone Squamous part of the temporal bone Greater wing of the sphenoid bone Parietal bone
  • ➤ Frontal bone
  • ➤ Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • ➤ Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • ➤ Parietal bone

questions.text: What is the diagnosis in the following radiograph?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spondylolisthesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spondylolisthesis is diagnosed radiographically by observing the forward slippage of one vertebral body over the one below it. It is crucial for appropriate management, which might range from conservative treatments such as physical therapy to surgical interventions in more severe or symptomatic cases.

questions.text: A woman comes with complaints of hyperpigmentation of her palms after an adrenalectomy. She also has new onset vision deficits. What is the likely diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Nelson syndrome occurs in patients who have undergone bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. After the adrenalectomy, the absence of cortisol feedback leads to increased secretion of ACTH by the pituitary adenoma. This results in:
  • • Hyperpigmentation: Due to elevated levels of ACTH and its precursor, which stimulates melanocytes. Vision deficits: Caused by the growth of the pituitary adenoma, which can compress the optic chiasma.
  • • Hyperpigmentation: Due to elevated levels of ACTH and its precursor, which stimulates melanocytes.
  • • Hyperpigmentation:
  • • Vision deficits: Caused by the growth of the pituitary adenoma, which can compress the optic chiasma.
  • • Vision deficits:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Sheehan syndrome : Caused by postpartum necrosis of the pituitary gland, leading to hypopituitarism. It presents with failure to lactate, amenorrhea, and hypothyroidism, but not with hyperpigmentation or vision deficits post-adrenalectomy.
  • • Option B. Sheehan syndrome
  • • Option C. Conn's syndrome: Primary hyperaldosteronism, characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. It does not cause hyperpigmentation or vision deficits.
  • • Option C. Conn's syndrome:
  • • Option D. Addison's disease: Primary adrenal insufficiency presenting with hyperpigmentation due to high ACTH, but it is not typically associated with vision deficits or occurring after adrenalectomy.
  • • Option D. Addison's disease:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nelson syndrome is characterized by hyperpigmentation and vision deficits following bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing's disease, due to the growth of an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma.

questions.text: Calculate the percentage of burns in a 6-year-old child whose head and neck was burnt in an accident at school? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 18%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients. For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA. This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.
  • ➤ Understanding the Lund and Browder chart is essential for accurately assessing burn injuries in pediatric patients.
  • ➤ For children aged 1-9 years, the head and neck region accounts for 18% of the TBSA.
  • ➤ This knowledge is crucial for determining the appropriate treatment and management of burn injuries in children.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

questions.text: Audiogram of a patient is given. Find the sign that can be seen in the same case. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Schwartz sign

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz on an audiogram is a specific finding in otosclerosis, and Schwartz sign, a reddish hue behind the tympanic membrane, is an associated clinical sign indicating active otosclerotic processes.

questions.text: In a patient who has undergone gastrectomy, vitamin supplementation required is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vit B12

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients who have undergone a gastrectomy require supplemental Vitamin B12 due to the loss of intrinsic factor, which is necessary for the absorption of this vitamin

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lung Abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lung abscess is identified by a cavity with an air-fluid level on imaging, differentiating it from other pulmonary conditions like TB, fungal infections, and hydropneumothorax.

questions.text: Identify the site marked in given barium follow-through of small intestine.(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Jejunum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The jejunum can be identified in imaging by the presence of valvulae conniventes creating a feathery appearance, distinguishing it from the ileum and colon.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes simplex virus (HSV), is characterized by steps involving the fusion of the virus with the plasma membrane, nuclear entry, transcription, replication, capsid assembly, glycosylation, and virus release.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has come with history of lower back pain and stiffness since 3 months. His ESR and CRP levels are raised. He has mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion is 3 cms. History of red eye is also there. The most likely diagnosis from amongst the following would be:(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ankylosing spondylitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presence of lower back pain and stiffness since months, raised levels of ESR and CRP, mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion, with history of red eye are suggestive of presence of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • ➤ Presence of lower back pain and stiffness since months, raised levels of ESR and CRP, mild restriction of chest movements and chest expansion, with history of red eye are suggestive of presence of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: Korsakoff psychosis is true except? (INICET MAY 2024) Amnesia Confabulation Ophthalmoplegia Ataxia
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Korsakoff psychosis is primarily characterized by amnesia and confabulation, not by ophthalmoplegia or ataxia, which are associated with the acute Wernicke's encephalopathy phase of thiamine deficiency

questions.text: A student got his jaw locked while yawning. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Lateral pterygoid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is the lateral pterygoid.
  • • The lateral pterygoid muscle has two heads: superior (or upper) and inferior (or lower). The superior head attaches to the articular disc and the capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). This muscle plays a crucial role in the opening of the mouth, protrusion of the mandible, and moving the jaw from side to side. Dysfunction or spasms of this muscle could contribute to jaw locking during yawning. The lateral pterygoid is, therefore, closely associated with the movements and function of the TMJ.
  • • All Innervated by CN V 3
  • • All Innervated by CN V 3
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Temporalis: The temporalis muscle originates from the temporal fossa and inserts onto the coronoid process of the mandible. It's primarily responsible for closing the mouth and is involved in elevating and retracting the mandible. It does not attach to the articular disc of the TMJ, but it plays a role in jaw movement.
  • • Option B. Temporalis:
  • • Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle is similar in function to the masseter muscle and helps in elevating the mandible, thus assisting in closing the mouth. It also plays a role in moving the jaw from side to side. However, like the temporalis, it doesn't directly attach to the articular disc of the TMJ.
  • • Option C. Medial pterygoid:
  • • Option D. Masseter: The masseter muscle is one of the primary muscles of mastication (chewing). It originates from the zygomatic arch and inserts onto the lateral aspect of the mandibular angle and ramus. Its primary function is to elevate the mandible, assisting in closing the mouth. It does not have an attachment to the articular disc of the TMJ but is important for jaw function.
  • • Option D. Masseter:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral pterygoid muscle, particularly its superior head, is uniquely attached to the TMJ's articular disc and plays a pivotal role in jaw movements including mouth opening and lateral movements, making it relevant in cases of jaw locking.

questions.text: A 65-year-old PLHIV patient came with cough, fever, and pneumonia. Biopsy shown in the image. Choose the correct agent: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CMV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of "owl eye" inclusion bodies in both the nucleus and cytoplasm of cells in a biopsy is indicative of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection, particularly in immunocompromised patients such as those living with HIV.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with symptoms of an inguinal hernia. During the operation, the surgeon observes a segment of necrotic bowel in the hernial sac. What is the appropriate course of action for resection and anastomosis of a necrotic bowel seen during surgery? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut.

options.label: B
options.text: The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures.

options.label: C
options.text: The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

options.label: D
options.text: The surgeon must use the single- layer seromuscular suture technique.

questions.correct_answer: C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The surgeon must use the single layer, extramucosal suture technique.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The single-layer extramucosal suture technique is the preferred method in small bowel anastomosis to reduce complications such as bleeding, strictures, and anastomotic leaks.

questions.text: A patient with a recent MI underwent coronary angiography, which revealed a block in the anterior interventricular artery. The infarction is likely to be present in which of the following regions of the heart? (FMGE JULY 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior wall of the left ventricle

options.label: D
options.text: Inferior surface of the right ventricle

questions.correct_answer: B. Anterior wall of the left ventricle
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anterior wall of the left ventricle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient with recent myocardial infarction (MI), who underwent coronary angiography, revealed a block in the anterior interventricular artery (also known as the left anterior descending artery or LAD).
  • • The LAD is a branch of the left coronary artery and is commonly referred to as the "widow's artery" due to its high incidence of involvement in angina and MI. The LAD runs along the anterior side of the heart and supplies the apex of the ventricle. The left coronary artery is the main artery supplying the left ventricle. Therefore, a block in the LAD would most likely result in an infarction in the anterior wall of the left ventricle.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Posterior part of interventricular septum: Incorrect. The posterior part of the interventricular septum is primarily supplied by the posterior descending artery (PDA), which is usually a branch of the right coronary artery (RCA) or sometimes the left circumflex artery (LCX).
  • • Option A. Posterior part of interventricular septum:
  • • Option C. Lateral part of the heart: Incorrect. The lateral part of the heart is mainly supplied by the left circumflex artery (LCX), another branch of the left coronary artery.
  • • Option C. Lateral part of the heart:
  • • Option D. Inferior surface of the right ventricle: Incorrect. The inferior surface of the right ventricle is supplied by the right coronary artery (RCA) and its branches, such as the marginal branch and the posterior descending artery (PDA).
  • • Option D. Inferior surface of the right ventricle:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle, and a block in this artery can lead to an infarction in this region of the heart.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tumor shown in the radiograph? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Epiphyseal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.
  • ➤ Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.

questions.text: In a patient presenting with recurrent chalazion, which cancer is suspected? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sebaceous cell carcinoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Sebaceous cell carcinoma is a malignancy of the sebaceous glands, which can present as recurrent chalazion.
  • • Chalazion is an inflammation of the meibomian glands , which are modified sebaceous glands located in the eyelids.
  • • meibomian glands
  • • While chalazion is typically a benign condition, its recurrence, particularly in elderly patients, can be indicative of underlying sebaceous cell carcinoma.
  • • This carcinoma is notorious for masquerading as benign eyelid lesions, thus a history of recurrent chalazion warrants further investigation to rule out this malignancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma : This is the second most common type of eyelid cancer, but it does not typically present as recurrent chalazion. It more often presents as a chronic, non-healing ulcerative lesion.
  • • Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma
  • • second most common
  • • Option C. Basal cell carcinoma : This is the most common eyelid cancer but usually presents as a pearly nodule with telangiectasia rather than as recurrent chalazion.
  • • Option C. Basal cell carcinoma
  • • most common eyelid cancer
  • • Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma : This vascular tumor is associated with immunocompromised states such as HIV/AIDS. It typically presents as red or purple macules, plaques, or nodules, not as recurrent chalazion.
  • • Option D. Kaposi’s sarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recurrent chalazion should raise suspicion for sebaceous cell carcinoma, especially in elderly patients, as this malignancy can mimic benign eyelid lesions.

questions.text: The lesion in Broadmann’s area 22 causes: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lesion in Broadmann’s area 22, known as Wernicke’s area, leads to receptive aphasia, characterized by fluent but nonsensical speech and impaired comprehension.

questions.text: Mention the true statement/s about drug resistant malaria: ( AIIMS May 2019) It is not present in India. Quinine with clindamycin or doxycycline is still effective treatment. Chloroquine with sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine is effective. Artemether with lumefantrine is useful. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is not useful due to high risk of recrudescence.
questions.correct_answer: A. b, d and e only
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Drug-resistant malaria in India is effectively treated with ACTs like Artemether with lumefantrine. Monotherapy with artemisinin derivatives is avoided due to the risk of recrudescence.

questions.text: You are applying a vacuum to deliver a baby in a patient with prolonged 2nd stage. The point at which the vacuum is applied is: (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

options.label: B
options.text: 6 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

options.label: C
options.text: 4 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

options.label: D
options.text: Midway between the anterior and posterior fontanelle

questions.correct_answer: A. 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flexion point, located 3 cm anterior to the posterior fontanelle, is the optimal site for applying a vacuum during delivery to achieve the necessary head flexion.
